TEXT: CARDINAL . ORG The applicant , PERSON , was born in DATE and lives in the GPE . From DATE until her retirement in DATE she worked in the police service .
CARDINAL . ORG In DATE PERSON was appointed to the rank of Assistant Chief Constable with the GPE police . As such she became the most senior - ranking female police officer in GPE .

CARDINAL . ORG On CARDINAL occasions during DATE , PERSON applied unsuccessfully to be appointed to the rank of Deputy Chief Constable , in response to vacancies arising within GPE and other police authorities . In order to be considered for promotion to this rank , ORG approval was required . However , according to the applicant , this was consistently withheld on the recommendation of the Chief Constable of the GPE police , who objected to her commitment to equality of treatment between men and women .

CARDINAL . ORG Following a further refusal to promote her in DATE , PERSON commenced proceedings on DATE in ORG against , inter alia , the Chief Constable of GPE and the Home Secretary , claiming that she had been discriminated against on grounds of sex .
On DATE , the Chairman and Vice - Chairman of ORG were designated a " Special Committee " to handle the issues arising from the discrimination case .

CARDINAL . PERSON alleges that certain members of ORG launched a " campaign " against her in response to her complaint to ORG . This took the form , inter alia , of leaks to the press , interception of her telephone calls ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) and the decision to bring disciplinary proceedings against her .

CARDINAL . ORG Thus , on DATE , ORG referred to the Senior Officers’ Disciplinary Committee a report written by the Chief Constable about an alleged incident of misconduct on the part of PERSON on DATE . ORG resolved , on DATE , to hold a formal investigation and to refer the matter to ORG and , on DATE , to press charges . PERSON was suspended from duty on full pay from DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG She challenged the above decisions by way of judicial review in ORG . The matter was adjourned by Mr ORG in DATE in view of a possible settlement . However , the parties failed to reach agreement and the matter came back before him on DATE . He found that the Chairman and Vice - Chairman of ORG had acted ultra vires and , without imputing ill - motive to them , held that there had been an element of unfairness . He therefore quashed the relevant decisions .

CARDINAL . ORG The hearing before ORG took place in DATE . On DATE the proceedings were adjourned pending negotiation between the parties , which led to settlement of the case . PERSON was given an ex gratia payment of MONEY ( GBP ) by the Chief Constable ( the statutory maximum which ORG could have awarded ) , together with GBP CARDINAL towards her personal expenses by the Home Secretary . It was agreed that she would retire from the police force on medical grounds ( arising out of an injury to her knee in DATE ) . In addition , ORG agreed to implement various proposals put by ORG , inter alia to update and review selection procedures for senior posts within the police force .

CARDINAL . ORG As Assistant Chief Constable , PERSON was provided with her own office and QUANTITY telephones , CARDINAL of which was for private use . These telephones were part of the GPE police internal telephone network , a telecommunications system outside the public network . No restrictions were placed on the use of these telephones and no guidance was given to her , save for an assurance which she sought and received from the Chief Constable shortly after she instituted the proceedings in ORG that she had authorisation to attend to the case while on duty , including by telephone .

In addition , since she was frequently " on call " , a substantial part of her home telephone costs were paid by the GPE police . Her home telephone consisted of a telephone apparatus connected , through the " network termination point " , to the public telecommunications network .

CARDINAL . ORG She alleges that calls made from her home and her office telephones were intercepted for the purposes of obtaining information to use against her in the discrimination proceedings . In support of these allegations she adduced various items of evidence before the Commission ( see paragraph CARDINAL of the ORG ’s report ) . In addition , she informed the ORG that she was told by an anonymous source on DATE that , shortly before , the source had discovered the GPE police checking transcripts of conversations made on her home telephone .

For the purposes of the case before the ORG , the ORG accepted that the applicant had adduced sufficient material to establish a reasonable likelihood that calls made from her office telephones were intercepted . They did not , however , accept that she had adduced sufficient material to establish such a reasonable likelihood in relation to her home telephone .

CARDINAL . PERSON raised her concerns about the interception of her calls before ORG on DATE . On DATE , in the course of the hearing , counsel for the Home Secretary expressed the opinion that it was not possible for her to adduce evidence about the alleged interceptions before ORG because section CARDINAL of the Interception of Communications Act DATE ( " the CARDINAL Act " ) expressly excluded the calling of evidence before any court or tribunal which tended to suggest that an offence under LAW had been committed ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE PERSON applied to ORG ( " the ORG " ) for an investigation under LAW ( see paragraphs CARDINAL - CARDINAL below ) . In a letter dated CARDINAL DATE , the ORG informed her that its investigation had satisfied it that there had been no contravention of sections CARDINAL to CARDINAL of the DATE Act in her case ( see paragraphs CARDINAL below ) . In a letter dated DATE , the ORG confirmed that it could not specify whether any interception had in fact taken place ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . ORG In a letter to Mr PERSON MP dated CARDINAL DATE , ORG Secretary explained that PERSON complaint regarding the interception of calls made from her office telephones " [ did ] not fall within [ his ] responsibilities as Home Secretary nor within the terms of the [ DATE ] LAW .

CARDINAL . The Interception of Communications Act DATE came into force on DATE following the ORG ’s judgment in ORG v. the GPE ( DATE , Series A no . CARDINAL ) . Its objective , as outlined in ORG which preceded it , was to provide a clear statutory framework within which the interception of communications on public systems would be authorised and controlled in a manner commanding public confidence ( Interception of Communications in GPE ( DATE ) ORG , PERSON . DATE ) .

CARDINAL . ORG A " public " telecommunications system is defined as a telecommunications system which is run pursuant to a licence granted under LAW DATE ( " LAW " ) and which has been designated as such by the Secretary of ORG ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the DATE Act , by reference to section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of LAW ) .
CARDINAL . ORG By LAW , anyone who intentionally intercepts a communication in the course of its transmission by means of a public communications system is guilty of a criminal offence .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) and ( CARDINAL ) provide CARDINAL circumstances in which a person who intercepts communications in this way will not be guilty of the offence . The only one of these which is relevant to the present case is the interception of a communication pursuant to a warrant issued by the Secretary of ORG under LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the DATE LAW provides that no evidence shall be adduced by any party , in any proceedings before a court or tribunal , which tends to suggest either that an offence under LAW CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act has been committed by a public servant or that a warrant has been issued to such a person under LAW .

CARDINAL . Sections CARDINAL to CARDINAL of the DATE Act set out detailed rules for the issuing of warrants by the Secretary of ORG for the interception of communications and the disclosure of intercepted material . Thus , section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the DATE Act provides :
" The Secretary of ORG shall not issue a warrant ... unless he considers that the warrant is necessary –
( a ) in the interests of national security ;
( b ) for the purpose of preventing or detecting serious crime ; or
( c ) for the purposes of safeguarding the economic well - being of GPE . "

When considering whether it is necessary to issue a warrant , the Secretary of ORG must take into account whether the information which it is considered necessary to acquire could reasonably be acquired by other means ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) of the CARDINAL Act ) .

CARDINAL . ORG The warrant must specify the person who is authorised to do the interception , and give particulars of the communications to be intercepted , such as the LOC from which the communications will be made and the names of the individuals concerned ( sections CARDINAL ( CARDINAL ) and CARDINAL of the DATE Act ) .

CARDINAL . ORG A warrant can not be issued unless it is under the hand of the Secretary of ORG himself or , in an urgent case , under the hand of a senior official where the Secretary of ORG has expressly authorised the issue of the warrant . A warrant issued under the hand of the Secretary of ORG is valid for DATE ; CARDINAL issued under the hand of an official is only valid for DATE . In defined circumstances , warrants may be modified or renewed ( sections CARDINAL and CARDINAL of the DATE Act ) .
CARDINAL . Section CARDINAL of the LAW provides , inter alia , for the limitation of the extent to which material obtained pursuant to a warrant may be disclosed , copied and retained .

CARDINAL . ORG The DATE Act also provided for the establishment of an Interception of Communications Tribunal . The ORG consists of CARDINAL members , each of whom must be a lawyer of not less than ten years’ standing , who hold office for DATE subject to reappointment ( section CARDINAL of and Schedule CARDINAL to the CARDINAL Act ) .

CARDINAL . ORG Any person who believes , inter alia , that communications made by or to him may have been intercepted in the course of their transmission by means of a public telecommunications system can apply to the ORG for an investigation . If the application does not appear to the ORG to be frivolous or vexatious , it is under a duty to determine whether a warrant has been issued , and if so , whether it was issued in accordance with LAW . In making this determination , the ORG applies " the principles applicable by a court on application for judicial review " ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL)-(CARDINAL ) of the DATE Act ) .

CARDINAL . ORG If the ORG determines that there has been no breach of the DATE Act , it will inform the complainant , but it will not confirm whether there was no breach because there was no authorised interception or because , although there was such an interception , it was justified under the terms of the DATE Act . In cases where the ORG finds there has been a breach , it has a duty to make a report of its findings to the Prime Minister and a power to notify the complainant . It also has the power , inter alia , to order the quashing of the warrant and the payment of compensation to the complainant . The ORG does not give reasons for its decisions and there is no appeal from a decision of the ORG ( section CARDINAL ( CARDINAL)-(CARDINAL ) of the DATE Act ) .

CARDINAL . ORG The DATE Act also makes provision for the appointment of a Commissioner by the Prime Minister . The first Commissioner was Lord Justice Lloyd ( now Lord Lloyd ) , succeeded in DATE by Lord PERSON , also a senior member of the judiciary , who was in turn succeeded in DATE by another , Lord PERSON .

CARDINAL . ORG The Commissioner ’s functions include reviewing the carrying out by the Secretary of ORG of the functions conferred on him by sections CARDINAL to CARDINAL of the DATE Act , reporting to the Prime Minister breaches of sections DATE the DATE Act which have not been reported by the ORG and making an DATE report to the Prime Minister on the exercise of his functions . This report must be laid before ORG , although the Prime Minister has the power to exclude any matter from it the publication of which would be prejudicial to national security , to the prevention or detection of serious crime or to the well - being of GPE . The report must state if any matter has been excluded ( section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act ) .

CARDINAL . ORG In general , the reports of the Commissioner to the Prime Minister have indicated an increase in new warrants issued , but the Commissioner has been satisfied that in all cases those new warrants were justified under LAW .

CARDINAL . ORG LAW does not apply to telecommunications systems outside the public network , such as the internal system at GPE police headquarters , and there is no other legislation to regulate the interception of communications on such systems .

CARDINAL . ORG The LANGUAGE common law provides no remedy against interception of communications , since it " places no general constraints upon invasions of privacy as such " ( Mr Justice PERSON in NORP v. ORG , ex parte ORG , DATE , unreported ) .
